On Saturday, September 17 at 8:30 pm EST, an explosion rocked West 23 Street in Manhattan, in the neighborhood commonly referred to as Chelsea, injuring 29 people, smashing windows and initiating street closures. There were no fatalities. Officials maintain that a homemade bomb, which had been placed in a dumpster, created the explosion. The explosive device was removed by the police at 2:25 am and was sent to a lab in Quantico, Virginia for analysis. A second device, which has been described as a ìpressure cookerî device similar to the device used for the Boston Marathon bombing in 2013, was found on West 27th Street between the Avenues of the Americas and Seventh Avenue. By Sunday morning, all 29 people had been released from the hospital. The Chelsea incident came on the heels of an incident Saturday morning in Seaside Heights, New Jersey where a bomb exploded in a trash can along a route where thousands of runners were present to run a 5K Marine Corps charity race. There were no casualties. By Sunday afternoon, law enforcement had learned that the NY and NJ explosives were traced to the same person.

Given that we are now living in a world where acts of terrorism are increasingly more prevalent, when a bomb goes off, our first thought usually goes to the possibility of terrorism. After all, in the last year alone, we have had several significant incidents with a massive number of casualties and injuries in Paris, San Bernardino California, Orlando Florida and Nice, to name a few. And of course, last week we remembered the 15th anniversary of the September 11, 2001 attacks where close to 3,000 people were killed at the hands of terrorists. However, we also live in a world where political correctness is the order of the day and the fear of being labeled a racist supersedes our natural instincts towards self-preservation which, of course, includes identifying the evil-doers. Isnít that how crimes are solved? Law enforcement tries to identify and locate the perpetrators of the crime or the ìbad guys.î Unfortunately, our leadership ñ who ostensibly wants to protect us ñ finds their hands and their tongues tied. They are not allowed to be specific about their potential hypotheses for fear of offending anyone.

New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio ñ who famously ended ìstop-and-friskî profiling in his city ñ was extremely cautious when making his first remarks following the Chelsea neighborhood explosion. ìThere is no specific and credible threat to New York City from any terror organization,î de Blasio said late Saturday at the news conference. ìWe believe at this point in this time this was an intentional act. I want to assure all New Yorkers that the NYPD and Ö agencies are at full alertî, he said. Isnít ìan intentional actî terrorism? We may not know whether it is from an international terrorist group such as ISIS, or a homegrown terrorist organization or a deranged individual or group of individuals. It is still terrorism. It is not an accident. James OíNeill, the New York City Police Commissioner had already ruled out the possibility that the explosion was caused by a natural gas leak at the time the Mayor made his comments. New Yorkís Governor Andrew Cuomo was a little more direct than de Blasio saying that there was no evidence of international terrorism and that no specific groups had claimed responsibility. However, he did say that it is a question of how the word ìterrorismî is defined. ìA bomb exploding in New York is obviously an act of terrorism.î Cuomo hit the nail on the head, but why did need to clarify and caveat before making his ìobviousî assessment?

The two candidates for president Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump also weighed in on the Chelsea explosion. Clinton was very generic in her response saying that ìwe need to do everything we can to support our first responders ñ also to pray for the victimsî and that ìwe need to let this investigation unfold.î Trump was more direct. ìI must tell you that just before I got off the plane a bomb went off in New York and nobody knows whatís going on,î he said. ìBut boy we are living in a timeówe better get very tough folks. We better get very, very tough. Itís a terrible thing thatís going on in our world, in our country and we are going to get tough and smart and vigilant.î

Unfortunately, an incident like the Chelsea explosion reminds us how vulnerable our country is particularly in venues defined as ìsoft targets.î Now more than ever, America needs strong leadership which is laser-focused on protecting her citizens from terrorist attacks of all genres and is not afraid of being politically incorrect.

The latest round of polls shows that the support for the Trump presidency is growing rapidly. The latest Fox News Poll, which was taken from September 11-14, shows Donald Trump polling at 46%, a one-point lead over Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton at 45%. The LA Times/USC poll taken from September 9-15 shows Trump at 47% with a six-point lead over Clinton at 41%. The gap between the two candidates is also narrowing in the key battleground states. Spearheaded by his daughter Ivanka Trump, Trumpís childcare policy offers something for everyone across the economic spectrum. The plan offers six weeks paid maternity leave to all mothers who do not receive this benefit through their employers. This benefit will be funded by closing gaps in our existing unemployment insurance program. Lower income families will also benefit from the planís offering of childcare rebates through the Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC) program up to $1,200 per year. Middle class families will benefit from being able to fully deduct all childcare expense on their tax returns. Families will also have the ability to establish Dependent Care Savings Accounts (DCSAs) to put money aside tax free for childcare. Low income families will receive a 50% match of the first $1000 deposited per year, generating up to an additional $500 per eligible family per year. DCSAs can be applied to pay for childcare, after school enrichment programs and school choice. Families can also use the funds in a DCSA to care for an elderly parentís expenses including in home nursing and long-term care. Finally, Trumpís childcare plan provides a tax deduction for stay-at-home parents, effectively eliminating the tax punishment for a parentís decision to leave the workforce to be a full time caregiver for child or an elderly parent.

Donald Trump followed his childcare policy speech with another economics speech to the Economic Club of New York which includes some of New Yorkís most powerful movers and shakers in the world of business and finance. Trumpís excellent week continued with his visit to the Dr. Oz Show where he released a letter from his long term doctor revealing the results of his most recent medical visit and other relevant pieces of his medical history. Other than carrying an extra 15-20 pounds, Trump appears to be in excellent health. Of course, Trumpís unveiling his medical records on a television show comes on the heels of the recent concerns about Hillary Clintonís health following her fainting at last weekís September 11 memorial event and the subsequent revelation that she was suffering from pneumonia. Again, only Donald Trump can turn the literal opening of an envelope into an event. Well, it is an event alright particularly if that envelope is opened on The Dr. Oz Show, a program which is reportedly watched by four million viewers daily with a large percentage of female viewers. During the one hour program, the discussion of Trumpís health was followed by the appearance of Ivanka Trump who was able to deliver yet another pitch about the newly announced childcare proposal to the aforementioned audience of women. So yes, somehow all this concern about Hillary Clintonís health and capacity to serve as president has created multiple free publicity events for Donald Trump.

Trump followed up the Dr. Oz interview with a visit to the Tonight Show with Jimmy Fallon. During the visit, Trump permitted the late night comedian to do something ìunpresidentialî. That is to say, he told Fallon that he could ìmess up his hairî. While most pundits would speculate that the moment was completely pre-planned, the fact that Trump said ìyesî to the display speaks volumes. He demonstrated that he has the ability to laugh at himself and that he is not afraid to have a bad picture taken. Furthermore, The Tonight Show is popular with Democrats and millennials of all political persuasions. Once again, Trump had an opportunity to make a connection with millions of people who more than likely were not on the ìTrump Trainî. Oh and one more thing, by letting Jimmy Fallon touch his hair on national television, Trump has finally set to rest all rumors that his hair is not his. However small, itís another check mark in the honesty and transparency box.

Now if all of this was not enough, Donald Trump capped his week off with an opening event ceremony at his new hotel in the former post office site in Washington DC where he received endorsements from military flag officers and fourteen Medal of Honor recipients. Trump used the event to not only promote his hotel project as being completed ìtwo years early and under budgetî, a metaphor for how he would manage the US economy, he also seized the moment to put an end to the ìbirther issueî. Trump took the microphone and said ìNot to mention her in the same breath,î (as the Medal of Honor recipients who had just endorsed him) ìHillary Clinton and her campaign of 2008 started the birther controversy. I finished it. I finished it,î he said. ìPresident Barack Obama was born in the United States, period. Now we all want to get back to making America strong and great again.î Trump said.

Once again, political correctness be damned, Donald Trump has had another ìamazing week.î

Peaceful protesters crowded Charlotte's first city council meeting since the cop shooting of Keith Lamont Scott, with over 50 people speaking out against police violence.

But none of them stood out Monday quite as much as a young girl.

Zianna Oliphant, her hair done up in braids and tears streaking her face, brought into focus the stress police shootings place on children, as well as the pain the black community of Charlotte has suffered in the wake of Scott's death last week.

ìIíve been born and raised in Charlotte. And I never felt this way until now and I canít stand how weíre treated,î the grade-school girl said, wiping away tears.

David T. Foster III/The Charlotte Observer via AP Photo

She expressed the hardship that children face when a parent dies. Scott himself, who was African-American, had seven children.

ìItís a shame that we have to go to their graveyard and bury them. And we have tears. We shouldnít have tears. We need our fathers and mothers to be by our side,î she said.

Zianna, as well as the protesters in the room who chanted "no justice, no peace" after she spoke, helped to underscore the degree to which communal wounds have been slow to heal in North Carolinaís most populous city since the shooting.

Protests started on the streets of Charlotte after news of Scott's shooting broke last Tuesday and, occasionally, became violent as they continued deeper into the week.

David T. Foster III/The Charlotte Observer via AP Photo

The scene grew especially tense Wednesday night when police clad in riot gear fired tear gas and rubber bullets at demonstrators. Some people in the crowds threw bottles and rocks at officers and passing cars, blocked an interstate highway, surrounded and jumped on vehicles, looted businesses and stormed the entrance of a Hyatt hotel, injuring two of its employees.

At the city council meeting, Charlotte Mayor Jennifer Roberts called for decorum at several points during public remarks. At several points, protesters yelled criticism of her and Police Chief Kerr Putney.

After the meeting wrapped up, The Charlotte Observer reported, more than 20 protesters moved to the lobby of the Government Center.

ìRelease. Release. The whole damn tape,î the protesters chanted, according to the newspaper.

David T. Foster III/The Charlotte Observer via AP Photo

Ray Dotch, Scott's brother-in-law, Monday called for the release of the entire video of his shooting in an interview with ABC News.

Chief Putney has released body and dashboard camera videos of the fatal police shooting of Scott, answering to demands made by community leaders, protesters and politicians. But it is not entirely clear from those videos or from the one taken by Scott's wife, Rakeiya Scott, that the victim had a gun on his person, as the police allege. It is also not entirely clear that he brandished it in such a way that would have posed a threat to the officers who approached him.
title: Young Girl's Emotional Council Speech Laments 'Shame' of Fatal Charlotte Shooting

Hillary Clintonís campaign is making one plea ahead of Monday nightís big debate: Donít let Donald Trump get away with it.

And Trumpís campaign is firing right back, arguing that the press is biased against the Republican nominee and, in any case, Clintonís team is just trying to ìgame the refs.î

Story Continued Below

The debate is playing out against a backdrop of polls that indicate a tightening White House race, with Trump drawing even or ahead in national and battleground-state surveys. Polling averages now show that Clintonís post-convention lead has evaporated, and no less a guru than Nate Silver declared on Monday morning that the race is a ìdead heat.î

ìThe latest polling is consistent with a Clinton lead of only ~1% nationally. State firewall breaking up. Trend lines awful,î Silver tweeted.

During the critical hours of expectation-setting ahead of the 9 p.m. showdown at Hofstra University, both camps claimed their candidate would be held to an unfair standard, with Clintonís aides explicitly requesting that moderator Lester Holt fact-check Trump in real time.

ìWe are concerned that Donald Trump may lie, he may throw misinformation out there, and that Hillary will have to spend all of her time trying to correct the record rather than talking about the things she wants to accomplish,î Clinton campaign manager Robby Mook told ìCBS This Morning,î adding that all the campaign is asking of Holt is that if Trump lies, ìthat that simply be checked.î

ìThe thing that concerns us is not the moderator themselves, who have been selected by the commission, because they will be seen as fair and even-handed. What bothers us, Mark, is the very public and very coordinated attempt to game the refs," Trump campaign manager Kellyanne Conway shot back in an interview on MSNBC.

But Conway was soon put in the awkward position of defending Trumpís claim that Holt may be unfair to him because heís a Democrat and the system is ìvery unfair.î The ìNBC Nightly Newsî anchor has been a registered Republican in New York since 2003.

ìI donít know that he knew what Lester Holtís voter registration was,î said Conway, who went on to dodge multiple queries of why Trump lied. ìHe didnít lie,î Conway said at one point, explaining that ìa lie would mean that he knew the manís party registration.î

In a presidential cycle thatís seen endless debates about debates, Mondayís theme was conflicting interpretations of what it means to be a moderator. After suggesting a debate with no moderator, Trump has already signaled to Holt that he shouldnít try to be Candy Crowley, who famously injected herself into the 2012 presidential debate between President Barack Obama and Mitt Romney with a fact-check of the GOP nominee.

But Clintonís campaign has beat up on Holtís NBC colleague Matt Lauer, who was widely panned in the media for allowing Trumpís false assertion that he didnít support the Iraq war go unchecked during a national security forum earlier this month.

View One week of Hillary Clinton fact-checks (September 24, 2016) One week of Hillary Clinton fact-checks (September 24, 2016)

The nonpartisan Commission on Presidential Debates, which selected the debate sites and moderators, weighed in Sunday. ìIn our history, the moderators have found it appropriate to let the candidates be the ones that talk about the accuracy or the fairness of what the other candidate or candidates might have said,î Janet Brown, the commissionís executive director, told CNNís ìReliable Sources.î

When it comes to fact-checking, Brown warned, ìI donít think itís a good idea to get the moderator into essentially serving as the Encyclopedia Britannica.î

For her part, Clinton wonít let Trumpís lies ìgo by the wayside,î press secretary Brian Fallon told CNN on Monday, insisting that Holt shouldnít, either.

ìThere is enough lies that Donald Trump tells consistently that everyone, by now, should be able to call them out,î he said. ìLester Holt, Hillary Clinton will, too, but I think that even the observers and reporters tonight watching that are grading the two candidatesí performances should take it into account. By now, we all know he likes to lie about his record when it comes to the Iraq war, he lies about his support for the intervention in Libya, he lies about who started birtherism, he lies on any different number of issues and he tells them so frequently that we all know them now. If he says them again, that should be disqualifying. He canít possibly be given a passing grade if he repeats those lies.î

Former Trump campaign manager Corey Lewandowski, a paid CNN contributor who is still receiving severance from the Trump campaign, dismissed the idea that a fact-checking moderator is of any concern.

ìI think what the concern is from both of the campaigns ó and what it should be ó is that the moderator is not the person whoís running for president of the United States. So I think you let the candidates debate, you let the candidates answer,î he said. ìYou can hold people accountable, thereís no question, but I donít think itís the role of the moderator to inject themselves in so theyíre making themselves part of the debate structure and people are talking about the moderator after the debate.î

Trumpís campaign, including his former aide Lewandowski, also pushed the narrative that Clinton is robotic. That charge was leveled in response to the Clinton campís preparation for two Trumps.

ìWe donít want Donald Trumpís lies and distortions to be a distraction. Weíre hoping that can get checked so that Hillary can focus her time on what she wants to do,î Mook told NBCís ìToday.î

Asked about Clintonís rules of engagement versus Trump, Mook added that ìit just depends on what Donald Trump shows up to the debate, and we just donít know that.î

View One week of Donald Trump fact-checks (September 24, 2016) One week of Donald Trump fact-checks (September 24, 2016)

But Conway shot down the notion that thereís any other Trump, while echoing the criticism that the former secretary of state lacks human compassion. Lewandowski cast Clinton as a policy wonk whose challenge is ìto become humanî during the debate, senior communications adviser Jason Miller tweeted that ìOverprogramming leads to short circuits,î and Conway joined the pile-on.

ìHeís not going to be robotic and scripted. Hillary Clinton is,î Conway said. ìAnd thatís a problem in debates likes this because people want to see a future commander in chief and president of the United States who is nimble and resilient and can answer questions that havenít been pre-programmed in their head through all this secretive debate prep and mock debates.î

After Mook warned against ìa double standard where Donald Trump can get the Most Improved award but Hillary Clinton, you know, is getting judged on the fine points of policy,î Conway added that the two campaign managers ìare living in parallel universes.î

ìI mean, Donald Trump has been criticized all weekend long. I think that the Clinton campaign has clearly been gaming the refs, has been talking to the media for a week now saying itís your job to make sure that Donald Trump is fact-checked in real-time,î she said. ìI'm just surprised a campaign manager would try to lower expectations that dramatically for his own candidate. But look, they know that campaign debates are not Hillary Clinton's sweet spot. Yes, she's experienced at doing them, but the experience hasnít necessarily been beneficial.î

Aside from how Holt will moderate, Conway cited pre-written narratives and what she claimed was Clintonís willingness to say anything to get elected as her top concerns.

ìIím worried that some of the headlines are already written, that theyíre conclusions in search of evidence,î Conway said, adding that newspapers and reporters have already begun trying to undercut Trump ahead of the debate.

ìWhat I would ask you all to do is start looking at the Twitter feeds of, quote, objective reporters, particularly our embeds. These are not profiles in courage, and this is not journalism. There are people who cover our campaign who actually just slander our candidate on Twitter,î Conway said. ìNinety-two percent of at least two of our embedsí tweets are negative towards Donald Trump. Why are they on our campaign plane? Why are they covering our campaign? ... Excuse the Trump campaign if we feel like we canít get a fair shake from certain people.î

Conway also indicated that Clinton may play the woman card, skewing headlines that take away from the real estate mogulís performance.

ìSo if she ends up saying to him, ëThatís just not true, youíre distorting my record, youíre being mean to a woman,í and then people will say, ëHe was mean to a woman,í and the headlines will scream and Twitter will blow up ó even if itís not true,î she said. ìSo that would be my concern, that heís not able to get out all of his responses because, as Joe [Scarborough] correctly points out, people are so worried that sheís not a great debater, that sheís not really ready for tonight the way he is, that sheís going to try to interrupt him and confuse the people watching in such a way that he was somehow rude to a woman and he somehow lied on the stage.î

Rudy Giuliani, the former New York mayor and a prominent Trump surrogate, said he had advised Trump to "just let loose" and be himself ó and not try to compete with Clinton's detailed policy expertise.

"She's been in government since I was a child. I don't remember a time she hasn't been in government in one way or another," Giuliani said on "Fox and Friends." "So she's going to have obviously more specific knowledge than he has, but I think he's going to comport himself very, very well, and he's going to be ó he's just going to be like you see him on ó when he comes here [on Fox News] and when you talk to him on the phone. He's going to be Donald Trump."

Indeed, this debate offers Trump the chance to perform what Iíve called ìpolitical judoîóturning an opponentís strength against her. (ìYes, Mrs. Clinton, your experience helped drag us into Iraq, and turned Syria, Libya, the whole Middle East into a staging ground for ISIS. Maybe thatís why your husband's CIA director, and Bobby Kennedyís chief speechwriter, are backing me.î)

Further, there's a senseóa highly limited senseóin which Trump is in something like the position Ronald Reagan was in back in 1980. Among college-educated whites, who have resisted him so far, his task is to use the debates to say, ìI'm a reasonable person who knows what's gone wrong and who has the instincts to fix it.î It's a second cousin of the 1980 situation where many voters did not want Carter, but needed reassurance about Reagan, which they got. (There is a limit to this analogy, because for all of her difficulties, Clinton is in a much stronger position than President Carter was).

By contrast, how does she try to gain strength on the issue of ìhonest and trustworthyî? If Trump can be convinced by his handlersóassuming they existóto avoid overkill here, all he has to do is to note what the FBI director or the New York Times editorial page has said. She can of course cite chapter and verse on Trumpóbankruptcies, Trump University, David Farenthold's expose of his charities in the Washington Postóbut those issues are ill-suited, I think, to a face-to-face debate. One of her problems, longstanding, is that the stuff of which campaign collapses are made have been leveled at Trumpóand he's still standing.

Does any of this mean that Clinton is facing doom Monday night? No. It does suggest that her campaign should remember what debates do and donít do, based on a half-century or so of history.

The Focus Is on ìMomentsîóBut Theyíre Not Always The Key

Ask any political journalist to recite the history of debates, and it would go something like this:

ìNixon looked pale and drawn; Ford prematurely liberated Poland from Soviet Control; Reagan said to Carter ëthere you go again,í then asked Americans ëare you better off?í Four years later, he was incoherent, but then recovered by joking about Mondaleís ëyouth and inexperience.í Dukakis was insufficiently emotional at the prospect of his wifeís rape and murder. Lloyd Bentsen told Dan Quayle was no Jack Kennedy. George H.W. Bush looked at his watch. Al Gore stalked George W. Bush, who froze him with a nod.î

These are the moments that are played over and over again in the run-up to debates. They illustrate the fact that these events are watched intensely for the quip, the gaffe, the thrust, the parry that can sum up 90 minutes. Itís why debate prep spends an inordinate amount of time trying to come up with punchy, memorable linesóìzingersîóto win the attention and admiration of the audience. (Itís also why the late political journalist Lars Erik-Nelson scornfully said of his colleagues, ìYouíve all become theater critics.î)

But in fact, this view of debates is not the whole story. Sometimes, itís the cumulative effect of the exchanges that can determine who prevails. Look back at the first Romney-Obama debate in 2012. There was no one exchange, no one Obama stumble or Romney answer, that provided the îaha!î moment that journalists wait for the way hounds wait for the first call of the fox. It was, rather, Obamaís petulant, defensive, sometimes indifferent answers that made even the presidentís most ardent supporters believe he had been badly beaten.

The presence of Trump clearly raises the odds that we may see a ìmomentî unlike any in debate history; thatís clearly what an army of reporters and tens of millions of viewers will be waiting for. But it may just be that it will be the totality of the hour and a half that will persuade a viewer to say: ìhe seemed pretty reasonableî or ìshe knows what sheís talking about and he doesnít.î This has special relevance for Clinton, who, as her longtime friend and one-time aide Patti Solis-Doyle observed, always seems as if she is testing every word before it leaves her mouth. A sustained, relaxed presentation over the course of the debate could be her best weapon against a Trump, whose ability to stay within himself when untethered to a Teleprompter is questionable.

There Are Three Debates, Not OneóAnd That Can Matter A Whole Lot

One key reason why the 1980 Reagan-Carter debate was so important is that it was the only debate between the two. Carter had refused to debate with third-party candidate John Anderson, so Reagan faced off against Anderson on September 21st. When the independent fell below the polling threshold, Carter and Reagan met for the first and last time on October 28thóbarely a week before the election.

Every other time, there have been three debates; which has meant there is a chance to make up for a less than successful debut. Thatís what happened with Reagan in 1984, and with George W. Bush in 2004; itís also what happened last time out, when Obama emerged from his daze and outperformed Romney in their two other meetings.

Here, I think, is an opening for Clintonóespecially in the town hall meetings, where she should be able to turn a questionóand they are usually very lame "what can you do for my daughter?" questionsóinto answers that fuse personal concern with a command both of her proposals, and of Trumpís astonishing inability to remember what he has proposed from one day to the next. The danger for her is channeling her inner Al Gore, who challenged Bushís commitment to health care by repeatedly demanding: "What about Dingell-Norwood?" The opportunity for her is to argueófrom experienceóthat what she has worked for in public life has made the lives of real people better. (Further, the Town Meeting formatówith dozens of ìrealî people as participantsómakes the resort to personal insults highly risky).

Trump Is Not the Only One Who Can Deploy Political Judo

The potential for Trump to turn strength into weakness has its roots in the most singularly successful use of political judo. It came in 1992, when independent Ross Perot was asked if voters should be bothered by his lack of experience.

ìWell,î he said, ìthey've got a point. I don't have any experience in running up a $4 trillion debt. I don't have any experience in gridlocked government where nobody takes responsibility for anything and everybody blames everybody else. I don't have any experience in creating the worst public school system in the industrialized world, the most violent, crime-ridden society in the industrialized world.î

Judo, however, can cut both ways. Thereís a clear opening for Clinton if Trump were to boast of his leadership skills, and his business success.

ìWell, you might be successful, Donald, but we really donít know because youíre the first presidential candidate ever who wonít show us his taxes. But you know, you should look at the business leaders who support me: Mike Bloomberg, whoís worth four times what you claim to be worth, and who didnít start with millions from his father, says youíre a con, a fake. So does Marc Cuban, who built his success from the ground up. But I do have to admitóyouíre way, way ahead of them in, unpaid workers, fleeced contractors and lawsuits.î

Debates Are NOT Decisive

One last note. Itís easy to assume that the fate of the world is at stake Monday night. A lot of post-election narratives over the years have located debates as the center of the story (ìReagan recovered from his first debate-gaffe and went onto win a landslide.î ìObama was far more effective in the later debates and was re-electedÖî). But is correlation really causation? Maybe the economic boom of 1984 has a lot more to do with Reagan winning 49 states; maybe the clear if modest economic recovery played the key role in Obamaís clear if modest popular vote victory.

In their influential 2013 book, The Gamble, political scientists John H. Sides and Lynn Vavreck tried to measure the impact of debates, gaffes, and other ìgame-changersî with real-time public opinion measurements. What they found was that even a dramatic event like Romneyís first debate performance had a relative small, and relatively short-lived, impact. Compared to the ìfundamentalsîóeconomic performance and the ever-growing impact of a polarized electorateóthe stuff of which a hundred overwrought post-debate analyses are made may be of only marginal significance.

Of course, this cycle the ìfundamentalsî point to a very close race. So youíll probably want to tune in anyway

Jeff Greenfield is a five-time Emmy-winning network television analyst and author.

(ìHonestly, it took me, like, 20 minutes.î) He explained that his parents told him from an early age that he should grow up to become the president of the United States so that he could eventually destroy the country from the inside.

ìIsnít that the plot of the first season of Homeland?î Hillary asked. Obama nodded. ìKind of. Also a little bit of The Americans.î

No one had come close to guessing his secret, until Donald Trump. He didnít know what had given it away. Heíd been so careful. Had Donald Trump figured out the secret messages he was sending through his Portuguese water dog, Bo? ìWait, what?î Hillary asked. She was starting to freak out. Obama explained that Bo was actually a supercomputer programmed to bark out messages in Morse code to terrorist organizations around the world, and he thought there was a chance that Donald Trump had seen that Boís eyes were really tiny LED screens. ìDid you know that when Bo barks,î Obama said, ìheís just repeating the word dog over and over again in a robot voice?î

Hillary was quiet for a long time. She had stopped eating her Popsicle, and the whole thing had just melted away. Now her fingers were stuck together, and it looked like she had one weird fish-hand. When she finally spoke, it was almost a whisper. ìYouíre a 97-year-old Kenyan Muslim man who was sent here by your ancestors to destroy America?î Obama nodded. Hillary made a strange sound and cried out, ìI feel like Iím short-circuiting!î Obama did his best to comfort her. ìBo does that sometimes. Then heíll go outside and poop out a printer cartridge.î

Hillary was breathing hard. She walked the length of the kitchen, then walked the width of the kitchen, and then surprised herself by doing the first tumbling pass in Aly Raismanís floor routine. Obama knew it was dangerous to tell someone his secrets, but it was such a relief. He felt light and loose. He felt 87 again. He took her hands into his. ìIím sorry my fingers are stuck together like a fish-hand,î Hillary apologized. ìDo you mean a fin?î Obama asked. They both chuckled with their mouths closed. Iím going to start my own terrorist group and call it ISIS.î

ìIsis?î

Hillary and Obama talked for hours that night. When they got tired of the kitchen, they moved outside to the Rose Garden with a six-pack, a joint, and, like, a ton of cheese. The pressure is on Hillary Clinton.

Insiders in both parties agree: Clinton, having lost most of her lead over the past few weeks and bringing more experience to the stage, faces higher expectations than Donald Trump when the two square off for the first debate on Long Island.

Story Continued Below

Thatís according to The POLITICO Caucus ó a panel of activists, strategists and operatives in 11 key battleground states. Roughly equal percentages of Democrats (69 percent) and Republicans (74 percent) said Clinton is under more pressure to perform than Trump. But Democrats mostly lamented the low expectations for Trump, a relative political neophyte who has exhibited little command of the issues.

ìShe shouldn't be [under more pressure], but so long as he avoids standing on stage and vomiting on himself, the press will give Trump a glowing review,î said a Nevada Democrat ó who, like all respondents, completed the survey anonymously. ìHillary will need a strong performance to demonstrate that she passes and Trump fails the commander-in-chief test.î

ìThe media and Trump himself have set the bar too low for Trump,î a New Hampshire Democrat added. ìPresidents don't get graded on a curve, and candidates in debates shouldn't be either.î

One Ohio Democrat detected a double standard for the first female major-party nominee.

ìHillary Clinton has spent a public lifetime of being held to a strikingly different standard, and this debate will be no exception,î said the Ohio Democrat. ìShe will have to answer every single question flawlessly, exude gravitas, look presidential, channel Bill's and Barack's oratorical mastery, not raise her voice, not cough, wear an acceptable pantsuit, smile enough, be likable, not laugh and have a good hair day. Donald Trump will just have to show up.î

Republicans also said Clinton was under greater scrutiny on Monday night, but for different reasons: tightening polls that show Trump eclipsing Clinton in some battleground states.

ìSomehow she needs to reverse the trend,î said an Ohio Republican. ìNever seen anyone do it before. This will be her chance ó and maybe her last chance.î

ìShe has to stop [Trumpís] momentum with a strong debate performance, and she has to be able to stand on the stage for 90 minutes and look healthy for 90 minutes or the whole issue of her health comes back with a vengeance,î added a Virginia Republican. ìAll [Trump] has to do is not say anything racist or sexist and look like he could be president.î

Among those insiders who said Trump was under more pressure ó 31 percent of Democrats and 26 percent of Republicans ó most pointed to the GOP nomineeís volatile personality.

ìHillary Clinton is expected to do well. She is a policy wonk,î said a Michigan Republican. ìThe pressure is on Donald Trump not to lose his cool. He has been doing very well in his public appearances, but that is with the assistance of a TelePrompTer. He will have no such help at the debate, and if I were coaching Hillary Clinton, I would be encouraging her to get him as riled up as possible. To win the debate, all Trump really needs to do is meet expectations, keep his cool, and look presidential.î

ìThe question we are all waiting to have answered is: Can he be serious?î added a Michigan Democrat. ìCan he answer questions directly? How will he react (or overreact) when he is directly challenged? Can he control his temper?î

Two other takeaways from the pre-debate survey:

Most insiders expect Clinton to ìwinî the debate.

Majorities in both parties peg Clinton as most likely to be the victor on Monday night: 76 percent of Democrats and 59 percent of Republicans.

ìMedia look at who best answered questions, and that will likely be Hillary,î said an Iowa Republican.

ì[Clintonís] mastery of issues and policies and no-nonsense delivery will prevail over bluster, name-calling and promises that can never be kept,î added a New Hampshire Democrat.

But not all Democrats were so optimistic about Clinton ó or the media through which voters will interpret the debate.

ìThe press wants Trump to win,î said a Florida Democrat. ìTheir disdain for her, plus desire to keep the race alive, means unless he really screws up, they'll give him the win on the most absurd grade curve ever.î

Some Republicans also claimed media bias ó in the other direction.

ìThe media has never been more in the tank for a candidate in modern history: CNN, NBC, ABC and POLITICO will all say she won,î a Virginia Republican said. ìBut then again everyone also 'knew' that Carter beat Reagan in their debate as well.î

Insiders think the debate will matter.

Asked whether they expect the debate to have a significant impact on the race, most insiders in both parties think it will generate momentum for one of the candidates.

Among Democratic insiders, 66 percent believe Clinton will benefit from the debate, 11 percent think Trump will get a bounce and 23 percent donít expect the debate to move the needle.

ìTrump will flounder, ramble and lie (because he always does),î a Michigan Democrat predicted. ìThe moderators will challenge him, and he'll get mad. He'll complain afterwards that they picked on him and favored Hillary. First impressions are hard to shake off, and this won't go well for him.î

The numbers were flipped for Republicans, with slightly less enthusiasm for the GOP standard-bearer: 52 percent think the debate will help Trump, 26 percent think it will help Clinton and 22 percent said it wouldnít have a significant impact.

ìTrump has the most to gain by appearing presidential and even-tempered,î said a New Hampshire Republican. ìHe does that successfully, and he cuts into Hillary's greatest strength.î

But some Republicans said Clinton could stunt Trumpís momentum with a strong performance Monday night.

ìIf she pins his ears back, [it helps her],î said an Iowa Republican. ìIf it's a draw, it's a net negative for her. She has to have something to stop his momentum. She's got to hit him with a brick.î

Other insiders, however, doubted whether the debate would have a significant, permanent effect on the race.

ìWe're past the era of the big debate swings: the bloodless Dukakis death penalty answer, the Reagan age quip, the Bentsen 'you're no John Kennedy' moments,î an Iowa Republican said. ìSwing voters are like the California Condor, a critically endangered species disappearing at an alarming rate. Opinion media, partisan polarization, and two highly unpopular candidates make this a battle over a very small group of voters in about a dozen states, and whatever bounce comes out of this debate will dissipate as quickly as it appears.î

Added a Florida Democrat: ìDoes a damn thing matter this year? I think not.î

CLEVELAND ó Donald Trump campaigned Wednesday morning in a church in a historically African-American community and sold himself as the candidate who could fix the problems of urban America. Within hours, Trump was proposing a vast expansion of ìstop-and-friskî policing policies that have proved explosively controversial in black communities for encouraging racial profiling.

It was just another day in Trumpís up-and-down black outreach campaign undertaken to wash away the stain of racism charges lobbed at him by Hillary Clinton and the Democrats.

Story Continued Below

The effort has taken Trump from a black church in inner-city Detroit earlier this month to addressing largely white audiences in rural North Carolina where, on Tuesday evening, he proclaimed in a small town named after a slaveholder that black communities "are absolutely in the worst shape that theyíve ever been in before, ever, ever, ever."

On Wednesday, Trump hit the campaign trail with former boxing promoter Don King ó who dropped the N-word before a group of pastors at a Cleveland church while extolling Trump as a ìgladiator.î King hailed Trump as the rare candidate who would overthrow the existing political system under which minorities have suffered.

ìThe system is the problem, and heís the only gladiator that will take on the system,î King said.

After the church event, Trump sat for a ìtown hallî with Fox News host and unabashed supporter Sean Hannity. Asked by an audience member what he would do to address ìviolence in the black community,î Trump embraced stop-and-frisk.

ìWe did it in New York, it worked incredibly well,î Trump said.

Fierce opposition to that policy in minority communities was among the issues that Bill de Blasio rode to prominence and, ultimately, the mayorís office.

But even before Trumpís stop-and-frisk comments, he was taking heat for his ìever, ever, everî remark Tuesday night.

ìI don't know what Mr. Trump is talking about to say that the situation for African-Americans is worse than it's ever been,î Rep. John Lewis, the Democratic civil rights icon, said Wednesday on MSNBC. ìIs he talking about worse than slavery? Worse than the system of segregation and racial discrimination ó when we couldn't take a seat at the lunch counter and be served? Worse than being denied the right to register to vote, to participate in the democratic process and live in certain neighborhoods and communities?î

Trumpís polling numbers among African-American voters have been dismal ó in the low single digits ó and some believe his outreach to black voters is as much about convincing moderate white voters, particularly women and those in the suburbs, that he is not racist. Trump regularly brings up his outreach to blacks ó ìWhat do you have to lose?î he says ó to largely white audiences.

At the New Spirit Revival Center in Cleveland, Trump assembled an eclectic kitchen cabinet of some of his closest advisers to attest to his beliefs before a diverse crowd.

Seated to Trumpís right was Mike Pence, his soft-spoken running mate. To his left, outspoken longtime attorney Michael Cohen. Behind him: King (ìthereís only one,î Trump said), former presidential rival Ben Carson (ìtoughî), retired Lt. Gen. Michael Flynn (ìa tough generalî) and former "Apprentice" star Omarosa Manigault (ìa wonderful womanî), who has helped with Trumpís black outreach.

ìIím different from a lot of Republicans, frankly,î Trump said from the pulpit.

Trump, who has called himself the ìlaw and orderî candidate, criticized the police officer who shot an unarmed black man in Oklahoma last week. Trump said he had watched the video and that the officer may have been ìchokingî in the fatal shooting. Trump has mostly defended the police in such incidents.

"Now, did she get scared? Was she choking? What happened? But maybe people like that, people that choke, people that do that, maybe they can't be doing what they're doing, OK?î

King, whom top GOP officials had pushed not to speak at the Republican National Convention due to a past manslaughter conviction, was given the prime slot of introducing Trump at a forum billed as a pastors leadership conference.

King, clothed in a sparkling jacket and clutching the flags of Israel and the United States, argued repeatedly that ìthe systemî had oppressed minorities and women and only Trump can upend it entirely.

ìEvery white woman should cast a vote for Donald Trump,î said King, who also went on an extended riff about the struggles of African-Americans.

ìI told Michael Jackson, I said if you're poor, you're a poor Negro ó I would use the N-word ó but if you rich, you are a rich Negro; if you are intelligent, intellectual, you're an intellectual Negro; if you're a dancing and sliding and gliding n-----, I mean, Negro,î King said.

When Trump took his turn at the pulpit minutes later, he grinned, ìAh, thereís only one Don King.î

Before King, Cohen, Trumpís attorney, used his time at the church to slash at the ìdisgusting, liberal, mainstream mediaî and its casting of Trump as a ìracist.î

ìThe word of the 2016 election has somehow become ëracist,íî Cohen complained. ìIíve lost count as to how many times the disgusting, liberal, mainstream media have attempted to label Mr. Donald Trump as racist, a xenophobe and a bigot. And letís not forget, sexist, misogynist, narcissist, Islamophobe, anti-Hispanic, anti-Semite demagogue. And countless others. Itís disgraceful.î

Cohen said, ìNot only is Donald Trump not a racist, he believes that all people are part of one race: the human race.î

Trump insisted that Democrats had abandoned black voters, and that he wouldnít.

ìThey come and they take your vote,î Trump said, ìand they say theyíll see you in four years.î

In March, in a bold ìOh yeah?î moment during an interview with the Washington Postís editorial board, Donald Trump took the paperís dare and revealed, then and there, his very short list of foreign policy advisers. There were just five, though he said, ìI have quite a few more.î The list was a head-scratcher, a random assortment of obscure and questionable pundits. One of the names, offered without elaboration, was, ìCarter Page, PhD.î

Who?

Story Continued Below

Reporters quickly Googling found that Page is the founder and managing partner of an investment fund called Global Energy Capital, and that he claims to have years of experience investing in Russia and the energy sector. As for his connection to Trump, when Page was reached for comment by the New York Times the day after Trumpís big reveal, he said he had been sending policy memos to the campaign and the paper said he ìwill be advising Mr. Trump on energy policy and Russia.î

This piqued my interest: I have been a Russia wonk for most of my adult life, I spent years living and reporting from Moscow, still go there regularly for reporting trips, and am in touch with lots of friends there. And yet, despite the tightly knit nature of the expat business community in Russia, no one I spoke to had ever heard of Carter Page.

ìWhatís this guyís name?î says one former Western energy CEO who spent years in Russia, and would have overlapped there with Page.

ìI had not heard of Carter Page before it came out in the media,î says another prominent Western businessman who has worked in the former Soviet Union for over two decades. ìBut I am getting a lot of emails from friends asking, ëHave you heard of this guy?íî

ìStrangely, I've never heard of Carter Page until this Trump connection,î Bill Browder responded to me in an email. He was one of the biggest Western players in the Russian market until President Vladimir Putin turned on him and Browder became his fierce critic. ìIt's odd, because I've heard of every other financier who was a player on Moscow at the time.î

Someone, apparently, has heard of him: On Friday, Yahoo News reported that Page was being probed by U.S. intelligence for purported back-channel ties to Russian leaders. The story resurfaced the name of a character whoíd all but vanished from the campaign, and reawakened questions about who, exactly, Trump was surrounding himself with.

This has been a concern swirling around the outsider candidate since he began, a real-estate developer with almost no serious Washington connections to tap for advice. ìIím going to surround myself only with the best and most serious people," Trump famously told a Post reporter last summer about how he would staff his campaign. "We want top-of-the-line professionals.î As the primaries unfolded, it became increasingly obvious that Trump would need all the top-of-the-line help he could get when it came to foreign policy. In an interview with conservative radio host Hugh Hewitt, Trump confused the Kurds with the Iranian Al-Quds Force, couldnít tell the difference between Hezbollah and Hamas, and couldnít recognize the name of the leader of ISIS. (In his defense, Trump said that ìHugh was giving me name after name, Arab name, Arab name, and there are few people anywhere, anywhere, that would have known those names.î) The Republican foreign policy specialists who would normally be a brain trust began slamming him in the press or publicly signing on to anti-Trump manifestos. And since they increasingly were fleeing the candidate, who were the people who would line up to advise him instead? What would they be like?

Enter Carter Page, a 44-year-old Ph.D., and business school graduate who claims an expertise in Russia and energy, yet who, I quickly discovered, was known by neither Russia experts nor energy experts nor Russian energy experts. (ìI can poll any number of people involved in energy in Russia about Carter Page and theyíll say, ëCarter who? You mean Jimmy Carter?íî says one veteran Western investor in Russian energy.) Page also, as I would be surprised to discover, appears largely unknown to Trumpís own campaign.

What I did find, however, is that while Page might not be helping Trump, Trump has been a significant help to Page. Since being named by Trump as an adviser, Page, who has spent his career trying to put together energy deals in Russia and the former Soviet Union, has finally begun to be noticed in the region. He is being treated in Russia as a person with potentially important ties in America. ìHeís an extremely well-informed, authoritative expert on Russia,î says Mikhail Leontiev, a pro-Kremlin talking head and spokesman for Rosneft, Russiaís state oil giant. ìPeople really respect him in this industry. Heís a very serious guy, and he has a good reputation.î According to the Yahoo report, U.S. intelligence believes Page had an audience with top Russian officialsóincluding Rosneft head Igor Sechinóduring a summer trip to Moscow. From what I could find about him, itís hard to imagine he could have secured those meetings without that mention by Trump.

Page has also been the subject of some breathless coverage in the American press. A March Bloomberg profile touted his ìdeep tiesî with ìexecutives at Gazprom,î the state-owned Russian gas giant, whom he says he advised on some of its biggest deals of the past decade. Last month, the Post ran a piece that was breathless in a different way, casting him as a shadowy broker with potentially important ties in Russia, some of them unsavory. The Yahoo story also portrays Page as a well-connected, high-rolling businessman with ìextensive business interests in Russiaî and an office ìaround the corner from Trump Tower.î

Page has fueled all this by making some remarkable statements, including saying Putin is a better leader than President Barack Obama to a June closed-door meeting of foreign policy Brahmins in Washington. In July, in Moscow, he spoke at the New Economic Schoolís commencement ceremony, a university that had hosted Obama just seven years ago. Page used the speech to slam the ìhypocrisyî of American foreign policy in front of a Russian audience, saying, ìWashington and other Western powers have impeded potential progress through their often hypocritical focus on ideas such as democratization, inequality, corruption and regime change.î He is now frequently quoted on Russian television, which hails him as a ìfamous American economistî and ìadviser to Donald Trump on questions of foreign policy.î

All of which reveals something deeply strange about Trump: when he shoots from the hip, his remarks do more than just whip up Twitter controversies. They also occasionally and unintentionally mint a new species of ìinsiders,î people who seem to be in Trumpís orbit but who may not haveóand may never have hadóany access to the gilded inner sanctum at all.

But someone is paying attention. As I started looking into Page, I began getting calls from two separate ìcorporate investigatorsî digging into what they claim are all kinds of shady connections Page has to all kinds of shady Russians. One is working on behalf of various unnamed Democratic donors; the other wonít say who turned him on to Pageís scent. Both claimed to me that the FBI was investigating Page for allegedly meeting with Igor Sechin and Sergei Ivanov, who was until recently Putinís chief of staffóboth of whom are on the sanctions listówhen Page was in Moscow in July for that speech.

So the question continued to linger: Who is Carter Page?

***

I should tell you before we get any further that Page wouldnít talk to me for this story. I called his fund and left messages, both on the general line and his personal voice mail. I emailed him repeatedly. I asked the Trump campaign to put me in touch. I emailed the Bloomberg journalist who interviewed him, who passed the request on. I even called Carter Pageís father in Poughkeepsie, New York, who told me he would ask his son to talk to me. But alas, no dice.

This was disappointing: No one who worked in Moscow when Page was there seemed to know who he was, and I just wanted to talk to someone who did. At a certain point, I just needed confirmation that he even existed.

OK, I thought. Try a different route. Maybe all these prominent Western businessmen who worked in Russia for decades didnít know Page, but maybe it was because some of them worked in different spheres of the Russian economy. He did, after all, have such an impressive rÈsumÈ.

Pageís biography on the website of his energy fund, Global Energy Capital, hits all the right notes. It was, at first glance, the rÈsumÈ of an up-and-coming player in the opaque but lucrative Russian energy market. ìHe spent 7 years as an investment banker at Merrill Lynch in London, Moscow and New York where he most recently served as Chief Operating Officer of the Energy and Power Group,î his bio reads. ìHe was involved in over $25 billion of transactions in the energy and power sector. He spent 3 years in Moscow where he was responsible for the opening of the Merrill office and was an advisor on key transactions for Gazprom, RAO UES and others.î

Those were some of the biggest energy deals of the 2000s, and Pageís tenure in Merrill Lynchís Moscow office, from 2004 to 2007, would have put him in the right place at the right time. He says he was part of the carving up of RAO UES, a massive Russian electric power holding company. He told Bloomberg that he advised Gazprom when it bought a stake in the Sakhalin II oil and gas project. Those were huge, huge things. If he were deeply involved, he would definitely count as a player. And surely he left at least a trace in the records of those deals.

So I called Ian Craig, the CEO of Sakhalin Energy from 2004 to 2009, who was doing the negotiations with Gazprom and stayed on as CEO after the deal went through. (It wasnít really a deal, to be clear: Sakhalin II was a large project in the Far East, and Gazprom essentially elbowed its way into the project when the government forced the consortium to sell the gas giant a controlling stake.) But Craig said he didnít know anyone named Carter Page. He was also surprised to hear about Merrill Lynchís purported involvement in the deal. ìI donít think Merrill Lynch or anyone else was front-lining the negotiations, because it was all done at the highest level, because it was very political,î says Craig . ìIt closed at CEO level, and eventually Putin himself signed off on it.î

When I asked a prominent Western businessman, who has worked in the former Soviet Union for over two decades and who is said to socialize with Sechin and other members of the Russian elite, about Pageís claim to Bloomberg that he advised Gazprom on Sakhalin II, he said, ìI rolled my eyes at that one.î (He, too, said he hadnít heard of Page until Trumpís announcement.)

Fine. OK. Maybe Page exaggerated a bit on that one. But what about the reorganization and privatization of RAO UES, the Russian electricity giant? Maybe some of the Russians he worked with remembered a Carter Page?

Turns out, they did.

ìHis nickname was stranichkin,î from the Russian word stranichka, or ìlittle page,î says Artem Torchinsky, who met Page during the breakup of RAO UES. Torchinsky, who was part of the companyís financial department, worked alongside Page, who, at the time worked in Merrill Lynchís Moscow office. It was 2007, and Merrill Lynch was underwriting the sale of one part of RAO UES, and Torchinsky was resentful of Page and the other Merrill Lynchers: Torchinsky and the in-house team did all the work, and Page and his team would swoop in to give the presentation. They were the fancy Western window dressing. ìIt really irritated our team,î Torchinsky told me over Skype. ìWe worked around the clock, and then they would come in and say something incomprehensible and weíd have to correct them. These guys didnít know what they were talking about.î As for Page, ìHe made no impression whatsoever. Whether he was there or not, it made no difference,î Torchinsky says. ìWhen youíre dealing with a pro, you see it. Page, unfortunately, did not leave that impression.î

OK, harsh. But then I talked to Pageís former boss, former Russian Central Bank Chairman Sergei Aleksashenko, who ran the Moscow office of Merrill Lynch for part of the time Page worked there. ìHe wasnít great and he wasnít terrible,î Aleksashenko says, exasperated and confused by the interest of all these journalists pestering him for information about someone ìwithout any special talents or accomplishments,î someone who was ìa gray spot.î ìWhat can you say about a person who in no way [is] exceptional?î he asked me.

Page was a vice president at Merrill Lynch in Moscow, which sounds senior but is a common title in the finance world; a big firm like Merrill Lynch might have thousands of VPs. In the Moscow office, there were five ranks, and VP was right in the middle. In effect, it was ìjust the oldest of the youngest, three from the bottom,î says Aleksashenko.

When it came to finance, Aleksashenko says, Page ìwas not a specialist in any branches of finance or in any instruments.î When it came to energy, Page and his team were, according to Torchinsky, ìmildly speaking, not competent in the field of energy.î And, says Aleksashenko, ìjudging by the drivel he spews on Russia, you can tell he doesnít really understand the topic.î

Trumpís putative adviser on Russia and energy and foreign policy, in other words, ìdid not create the impression of someone who was intellectual or well-educated, or someone who was in any way interested or knowledgeable in foreign policy,î says Aleksashenko.

***

For the past few years, Page has styled himself a foreign policy expert. He has written columns in Global Policy Journal, a new peer-reviewed journal run out of Durham University. They are confoundingly written and make logically curious leaps. ìIn recent months, renewed calls for equal justice have brought social tension across the United States after the killing of Michael Brown and Eric Garner by police officers in Missouri and New York respectively,î he wrote. ìAlthough commonly overlooked, the impact of other fatal mistakes by government officials in the foreign policy arena might vastly outweigh these tragic deaths in potentially catastrophic proportions.î He is the kind of thinker who writes that Kanye Westís ìNew Slavesî and the ìartistís creative work offers valuable ideas that could fundamentally improve the direction of U.S. foreign policy and world affairsî but does it by opening with a citation from the Oxford English Dictionary (ìSlave; Pronunciation: /slav/Öî), roping in Adam Sandler, William F. Buckley and Dick Cheney.

His speech in Moscowís New Economic School was a similar construction of empty spaces held together with repetition, tautologies, and abuses of the word ìironically.î ìFor the last 15 years, Iíve been researching, teaching, and writing about fundamental trends in the world economy, which have really continued to evolve in this period and in the years immediately preceding it,î he began. The video of the speech also suggests that after three years living there and a lifetime studying the place, he couldnít really speak Russianóhe had to have his questions translated for him into English. Except to quote, haltingly, brokenly, Vladimir Putin: ìWe never meddle in the internal political affairs of other countries. Unlike the USA.î Which is troubling for two reasons: that the adviser of a presidential candidate of a major party is criticizing America abroad by citing Putin, and that the comment implied that he seemed to not know anything about anything going on in, say, Syria or Ukraine.

Page also managed to find his way into a fellowship at the Council on Foreign Relations, where he cut a strange figure. Like other Westerners doing business in Russia, Page took the view that Putin was not the blood-stained and corrupt tyrant some in the West imagine him to be, defending him as a strong leader who brought order and prosperity to Russia. But unlike other entrepreneurial defenders of Putin, people at the Council recall that Page was not particularly good at it. ìHe had a guilty-seeming style in making these arguments, making it seem like he didnít really want to engage,î one person from the Council says. His columns made the rounds and raised eyebrows. ìThat blog post about the slaves. Thatís just Ö strange,î says the Council member.

ìHeís a nice guy, but of the people that I know that have Russian foreign policy experience or access and contacts, he wouldnít be in the last decile, but heíd be in the second-to-last decile,î says one American executive with experience in Russia and its energy sector. ìYouíd have to dip really far and wide to find a guy like Carter Page. I mean, wow.î

***

I shouldíve just dropped the Carter Page story, but in the months since Trump named him an adviser, the campaignís Russia connections have become a bigger and bigger issue. Fancy Bear, who was probably a Russian hacker, broke into the Democratic National Committee emails, seemingly handed them over to Julian Assange, who continues to leak the information in a way that is clearly designed to help one campaign and hurt the other. Trumpís second campaign manager, Paul Manafort, flamed out in August because of his shady business dealings with the pro-Kremlin side of Ukraine, and Trump himself continues to say absurd things about Russia and Putin, like publicly inviting the Russian government to continue hacking American servers. Washington was in full Hunt for Red October mode, and it was all I could do to stay on Pageís trail, which began to look more and more like an infinity sign.

I was not the only one. Seemingly everyone I talked to had also talked to the Washington Post, and then there were these corporate investigators who drew a dark and complex web of Pageís connections. Then there was Page, praising Putin. I found myself juggling two mutually contradictory Page narratives: Was Page, like Manafort, followed by a long train of sordid dealings with dark and powerful players with deep pockets and deep resentments toward the West? This was the person described by the corporate investigators trying to whisper into my ear. Was Page a man wheeling and dealing in energy contracts with China and Turkmenistan, who was a vehicle for the Kremlin to influence the American election? Was he a man who, during a three-day trip to Moscow, met with two of Russiaís most powerful men and was now being investigated for it?

But it was hard to see that man when I actually talked to people who knew him. Page made his way into the financial sector as it ballooned in the early part of the past decade, securing a spot at Merrill Lynchís London and Moscow offices. Today, he claims he was cozy with Gazprom executives; his former colleagues laugh at the suggestion. ìNo one let him into Gazprom,î Aleksashenko says. ìHe didnít go shake [Gazprom chief Alexey] Millerís hand. He made sure there were cars, hotels and meetings for investors in London.î Another of Pageís colleagues from Merrill Lynch confirmed that Pageís role was simply arranging meetings between Gazprom and Western investors, something normally done by analysts, the lowest rank on the totem pole. ìPeople organize meetings with Gazprom all the time,î the former colleague said. ìHe hosted these guys in New York City but they would have done this 10 times a yearÖ I used to do this; it doesnít require all that much skill. You just send out an email to 20 people saying Gazprom agreed to dinner at this place at 8 p.m., do you want to come? The main thing is just getting those two [Gazprom] guys to agree. But because they agreed doesnít mean theyíre close to him.î

But the meetings did provide him with something else. ìGazprom didnít need money at the time,î says the former colleague. ìThey were the most profitable company at the time. Their net profit was something like $36 billion a year. Their problem was not getting investors, but figuring out how to spend money in a non-efficient way if you read between the lines. He was probably aware of that. He would have known how inefficient and wasteful the company is.î Page became an investor in the company, and has, according to filings, advised other companies heís worked for to invest in them.

After Merrill Lynch, Page tried to set up his own fund to invest in energy projects and called it Global Energy Capital. But he tried to do this in 2008, and we know what happened to the markets in 2008. The fund is registered to his fatherís address in Poughkeepsie; Page listed himself as ìfounder and managing partner,î even though the only other partner seemed to be Sergei Yatsenko, who was once a mid-level executive at Gazprom. He also maintained a website and handed out business cards that listed a fancy Madison Avenue addressóthatís the one ìaround the corner from Trump Towerîó which was actually the address of a co-working space.

ìThatís Carter Page,î says an American businessman who has spent nearly a decade working in Russia. ìThatís what heís been doing, without any actual funding, without any actual experience, without any actual connections or core capabilities, heís been trying to throw together these deals. Heís always been operating at a level far beneath that at which business in Russia is done. I admire that, it takes a lot of gumption.î

In the interest of due diligence, I also tried to run down the rumors being handed me by the corporate investigators: that Russiaís Alfa Bank paid for the trip as a favor to the Kremlin; that Page met with Sechin and Ivanov in Moscow; that he is now being investigated by the FBI for those meetings because Sechin and Ivanov were both sanctioned for Russiaís invasion of Ukraine.

ìI donít know this person,î said Pyotr Aven, one of the two founders of Alfa Bank, which is considered the Western Russian bank. Aven and his partner, Mikhail Fridman, have transferred much of their assets out of Russia and have been quite critical of Putin. As for who paid for Pageís trip, Aven was no less irritated by the question. ìI give them money, I donít know how they spend it, who they invite, when they invite them, I have no idea,î he said of the New Economic School, which hosted Page and of which Aven is the main benefactor. Exasperated by my questions, he snapped, ìDonít bring these Russian-style conspiracy theories to me.î

ìYou are engaged in onanism,î said Leontiev, the spokesman for Rosneft and Sechin when I asked him if Page had met with Sechin. ìItís bullshit. Just bullshit. You need to understand who Sechin is to even ask this question. Itís hard to have a meeting with him at all. Itís absurd.î

As for the FBI investigation, well, itís unclear. A State Department official who works on Russia sanctions but was not authorized to speak on the record told me that, for one thing, there is ìno prohibition meeting with a designated [sanctioned] individual. Moreover, sanctions violations are not criminal in nature and not enforced by the FBI. OFAC runs them.î He added, ìthe story doesn't add up.î What does seem to have happened is that various U.S. intelligence agencies were looking into Pageís time in Moscow, then briefed Senate minority leader, Democrat Harry Reid, who wrote a letter to FBI Director James Comey asking him to investigate, among other things, ìwhether a Trump advisor who has been highly critical of U.S. and European economic sanctions on Russia, and who has conflicts of interest due to investments in Russian energy conglomerate Gazprom, met with high-ranking sanctioned individuals while in Moscow in July of 2016, well after Trump became the presumptive Republican nominee.î

***

I got my next surprise when I called Stephen Miller, Trumpís senior adviser. I caught him just as the Trump plane was about to take off, and asked him the tired, old question: Who is Carter Page?

ìWho?î says Miller, and then went off the record to expound on his lack of involvement in the campaign.

ìHe has no formal role in the campaign,î Hope Hicks texted responding to my question.

Now my interest was piqued. There were whispers all over Washington that, despite Hicksís denial, Page was not only still part of the Trump campaign, but its conduit for Russian influence. Was he?

One way to answer the question was to figure out how he even got on that list to begin with.

One source suggested to me that Richard Burt, former U.S. ambassador to Germany, START treaty negotiator, and longtime lobbyist for Alfa Bank, was the nexus. It was Burt who helped draft Trumpís foreign policy speech in April, and had been advising the Trump campaign, via Senator Jeff Sessions, on foreign policy. But when I met Burt at his office at the McLarty Associates lobbying shop, he looked at me and said he had never even met him. ìThe only person I talked to about Carter Page is this guy at the Washington Post,î Burt told me. ìAnd I told him Iíd never met the guy. Let me put it this way: if I have met him, Iíve forgotten. Heís the former Merrill Lynch guy, right?î

Someone else told me that the Page connection was Rick Dearborn, Sessionsí chief of staff, who hired Page because Dearborn knew nothing about foreign policy but needed to put together a foreign policy staff for Trumpís Alexandria, Virginia, policy shop and he happened to know Page. But Dearborn wouldnít return my calls, and someone who once worked for that policy shop told me it was neither Dearborn nor Burt, but campaign co-chair Sam Clovis who recruited Page. ìIf he was part of that original group of people, I can say with 70 percent confidence it was Sam Clovis,î this person told me.

ìIím not answering your questions,î Clovis told me. He refused to tell me if he was the one who found Page, but Jason Miller, the campaignís other spokesperson, says, ìCarter Page isnít someone Iíve interacted with.î Which confirmed what a policy staffer on the Trump campaign told me: ìCarter is a red herring, not a Rasputin. Heís never met Trump, never briefed him. He has zero influence, none.î

***

Was Page the shadowy messenger between the Kremlin and Trump Tower, or was he the nebbishy, not-very-successful man trying to profit from the arbitrage between what Trump saidóheís my adviseróand what his associates saidóìWho?î Maybe I wasnít doing this right, and maybe everyone was lying to me, but it was hard not to come to the conclusion that, regardless of whatever game the Russians were running, Page was firmly in the latter camp.

ìI donít know about his Russia fund, other than itís never really materialized,î says the prominent player in the energy space whom Page has pitched on various energy projects. ìEvery conversation Iíve had with Carter has not been terribly serious. Theyíve all been pie-in-the-sky ideas. There are usually issues with traction and execution capabilities.î He went on. ìI couldnít name a project that I could connect Carterís name to, any project that actually happened.î

ìI donít know how heís earned a living off this,î the energy player says, ìbut I think heís been trying to be an intermediary. If you hang around Russia long enough, itís sort of like a pinball machine, something will hit you.î

Strangely, it was not a Russian pinball that hit him; it was Trump. According to the Trump policy adviser, this winter, Clovis began to draw up a list of people who could serve as policy advisers to the campaign and give it some intellectual and policy heft. At a time when established Republican foreign policy specialists were tripping over each other to get away from Trump, ìa lot of people came to Sam Clovis in February, March, and said, ëI want to be part of the team,íî says the Trump adviser. And thatís how it happened. ìHeís just a guy on a list. Trump looked at the list and said, ëHeís an adviser.í And now heís milking it for all itís worth.î

Now, someone whom no one in the field had ever heard of was suddenly a Very Important Person in Washingtonóor at least could plausibly market himself as one. ìI was not aware of him at all until he was named to the campaign, and even after that, I had never heard of him,î one Russia specialist in Washington told me. He saw Page at a Washington roundtable in June for Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, and what he saw was a strange kind of person: one who was very differential to everyone there ìin a way that someone who is junior would use it to network,î but who was dropping hints full of meaning to anyone who would listenóand be impressed. ìHe was saying he was planning to go to Moscow,î the Russia specialist recalls. ìHe didnít say what he was going to do there, but he created the impression that there could be some meaning to the trip.î

According to a congressional leadership staffer familiar with the intelligence briefings on Pageís trip to Russia, ìthe meetings did happen and thatís been established as a fact. I think the investigation is more what happened in them.î But it remained unclear, the staffer told me unprompted, what this even meant. ìItís not just did he met with them or not, but now looking into the bigger question of what the hell is going on?î said the staffer. ìIs he acting as a conduit in ways that are against Americaís national security interests? Wittingly or un-, I should add. Itís whatís hard to parse about this. Is he doing this with nefarious intent or is this just about guys who are thrilled to be living in a John le CarrÈ novel? Or are they being played by much smarter people in the Kremlin?î

This seems to be vintage Carter Page, a man whose story never quite adds up, as much as he tries to make the numbers work. But heís also mastered the art of manipulating the distance between his story as it is and his story as he wants it to be, playing on the uncertainty in between to make himself seem more successful, more connected, even more evil than he really isóand to try to turn a profit off of that. ìIf Page using his status as ëTrump advisorí for personal gain, thatís another matter: Time for Page to join Twitter!î Michael McFaul, former U.S. ambassador to Russia, tweeted after news of the investigation broke. The Russians may be feeling out the Trump campaign via Page, but Page must be loving every minute of it. After all, meeting Russiaís energy czar is an impossible dream for a would-be investor struggling to make it in the world of Russian energyóbut the dream entered the realm of the possible when Trump said three words in March: ìCarter Page, Ph.D.î Now Carter Page, Ph.D., has found a perfect candidate to latch on to, like a pilot fish feeding off the carnage wrought by the oblivious Trump shark.

For months now, the American press has been twisting itself in knots trying to explain men like Page and Manafort, and, through them, to answer the questions of whether Putin is trying to destroy America by their hands, and is Trump a Kremlin stooge or a just a useful idiot, and is there even a difference?

There doesnít seem to be one in the world of Trump, which in some ways resembles Putinís: the waters of truth are muddy and deeply suggestive. And that is all that matters. Is Putin actually meddling in our election and undermining the foundations of Western democracy in a massive way, or doing just enough to make us think he is, and thereby acquiring powers he holds only because we believe him to have them? ìI want to hope that this is connected with the growing influence and significance of Russia,î Putin says of the rumors of Russian meddling in the American electionóas we in the media continue to squeegee them around, rarely really getting closer to the truth, and watching it disintegrate in our hands when we think weíve finally grasped it.

Julia Ioffe is contributing writer at Politico Magazine.
title: The Mystery of Trumpís Man in Moscow: Carter Page
